moves.1. e4 g6 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. Qf3 d6 4. Qb3 e6: White has Pe6.  BxPe6, BxBe6, QxBe6.
moves.8... Nc6: BxPe6 is even better as Nc6 is undefended.
moves.16. Rxe4 Qxf2+ 17. Kh2 Qf5: NxPe5 also works, as RxPe5 can be followed by Qf4+, giving black the rook and pawn for two knights.  6/6 makes up the knight.
QxPb2 is another possibility.  Black follows up with QxNa3 (where white gives up the knight to protect the rook with the white queen).  The drawback is that white picks up momentum.
moves.22. Qg1 Rf3 23. Qxf2 Rxf2 24. Na3 Raf8 2: Black nets a bishop in this exchange.
moves.35... Bxa6 36. Rf4 Rb3 37. Re4: Rf3 would defend Pc3, briefly.  Black wants even trades now, however.
moves.37... Rxc3+ 38. Kf2 b4 39. Kg1 a4 40. Bd: The knight was protecting Pb4.  Rc4 gives black Pg4, unless white trades rooks.
moves.41. g5 a3 42. Rc4: Oops.  The bishop that took Na6 will likely take Rc4.
moves.42... Bxc4 43. Bf4: White has no way to stop Pa1=Q now.
